image.altText: ACT Labor Leader Andrew Barr and Canberra Liberals Leader Elizabeth Lee stand on a stage behind podiums.

props.synopsis: Short and sharp, the half hour leaders' debate a week-and-a-half out from the ACT election left both sides content about their performance, and no clear winner or loser.

title.children: Five key takeaways from the ACT election debate between Andrew Barr and Elizabeth Lee

image.altText: Shoppers walk through Dickson shops in ACT during winter July 2012

props.synopsis: The ACT Magistrates Court sentences Christopher Lichtwark to nine months in jail, suspended from today, with an 18-month good behaviour order.

title.children: Man who chased three teenage girls asking for sex is allowed to walk free with suspended jail sentence

image.altText: Assala Sayara speaks at Pro-Palestine rally.

props.synopsis: Protesters have gathered outside Federal Parliament to demand Australia sanction Israel for its actions in Gaza and Lebanon, a day after commemorations a year on from the Hamas terrorist attack on southern Israel.

title.children: 'We come with rage': Pro-Palestine protesters say ongoing conflict taking emotional toll on local community

image.altText: A building sign that reads 'ACT Civil and Administrative Tribunal'.

props.synopsis: In its final ruling the ACT Civil and Administrative Tribunal found overwhelming support for the conclusion pit bull cross Buddha posed a risk to the safety of the public and other animals.

title.children: 'Threat to people and other dogs': Canberra owner fails to overturn ruling her dog should be put down

image.altText: Milk bottles in a supermarket fridge with a red 'Lower Shelf Price' sign in the window

props.synopsis: Coles and Woolworths say they’re passing milk price reductions on to shoppers. But what do shelf price cuts mean for the farmers who produce the milk?

title.children: Supermarkets drop milk price to lowest since 2010 as farmers fear return of 'milk war'

image.altText: Chloe Hosking raises her fist as she rides across the line

props.synopsis: One of Australia's most successful female road cyclists, Chloe Hosking, was forced into early retirement when her cycling team collapsed just weeks out from the start of the European cycling calender.

title.children: One of Australia's most successful female road cyclists' careers was cut short — and it's not uncommon

image.altText: Three school students look at phone

props.synopsis: As national leaders grapple with ways to best protect young minds from the potentially harmful effects of social media, students are already talking through some of the issues, and opening up about how taking time out from TikTok and other platforms has helped them live offline.

title.children: Students open up on TikTok detox amid ban talk, as platform reveals it booted a million underage accounts

image.altText: a close up detailed shot of a pink flower

props.synopsis: The endangered Beadle's grevillea only grows in a few areas in the wild. After a harsh drought, the species is now thriving and the couple that saved it wants the plant safeguarded for generations to come.

title.children: Rare grevillea in full bloom after couple nurses plants through drought

image.altText: A sign explaining preferential voting at an ACT election polling place.

props.synopsis: From news, analysis and explainers through to election previews, key electorates and candidates, ACT Votes has the latest on the upcoming state election. Click through to read more.

title.children: ACT Votes 2024 — stay up to date with the latest election news and analysis

image.altText: passersby walk by a tent made of an old sign on a waterfront promenade

props.synopsis: About 1.2 million people have been forced from their homes by Israel's bombardment and invasion, the Lebanese government says. They fill the public spaces around Beirut – footpaths, squares, churchyards and schools.

title.children: Beirut's famous waterfront taken over by people fleeing Israeli air strikes

image.altText: Illustration of autonomous self-driving cars.

props.synopsis: A Choice investigation has found most of Australia's popular car brands collect and share "driver data", ranging from braking patterns to video footage and voice recognition information.

title.children: Cars are data-harvesting machines. These brands share your personal information

image.altText: A group of Italian internees in Australia, WWII

props.synopsis: The impulsive fear and punishment of innocent people on the grounds of their appearance or garments or last name is a phenomenon you'd hope had disappeared — but it's a mistake we keep making.

title.children: Generations of foreign-born Australians have been punished for their heritage. It's a mistake we keep making

image.altText: A hand holds two Australian passports in Central Park, New York.

props.synopsis: A glitch in Indonesia's e-visa system is inadvertently exposing sensitive traveller information to strangers with at least three Australians able to see passport details of other people.

title.children: 'We are aware of this problem': Australian tourists say private details exposed at Bali Airport

image.altText: An older Lebanese man wearing a white turban and beard stares intensely

props.synopsis: The deputy chief's remarks were made in a televised address.

title.children: Hezbollah deputy chief says the militant group supports Lebanese efforts for a ceasefire with Israel

image.altText: A family of four embrace in outback Australia

props.synopsis: Outback tourism operators are feeling the squeeze as soaring costs and increasing global competition cut into visitor numbers.

title.children: 'Why are we waiting for retirement?': This family sold their home to experience outback Australia

image.altText: Sheila Raymond and family members

props.synopsis: Sheila Thurlow's family is calling for an inquest into her death at a Brisbane hospital after she was injected with 1,000 times the intended dose of morphine.

title.children: Nurse 'Googled' hospital procedure night before woman was given 1,000 times the intended level of morphine

image.altText: Storm cloud rolling into the outskirts of a city

props.synopsis: The first major outbreak of spring thunderstorms is firing up this week across parts of Queensland and New South Wales, bringing with them threats of the destructive supercell storm.

title.children: Thunderstorms bring threat of supercells to Queensland and NSW with destructive winds and hail on the forecast

image.altText: A woman sits at a desk in front of writing on the wall which reads: 'Fiji Independent Commission Against Corruption'

props.synopsis: Dramatic developments at Fiji's Independent Commission Against Corruption reveal broader teething problems with the country's transition from dictatorship to democracy.

title.children: Fiji corruption official Francis Puleiwai told police to arrest her new boss. Then she fled to Australia

image.altText: Donald Trump stands at a podium, holds his hands outstretched and smiles.

props.synopsis: Australia would be among the countries that would suffer most from what Trump is proposing, after the US and China.

title.children: From mass deportations to huge tariff hikes, here's what Trump's economic program would do to the US and Australia

image.altText: A photo of a man with a beard wearing a white and red shirt.

props.synopsis: Paniora Nukunuku was confused when he walked into his local Woolworths and saw a new red label with the words "low prices" on his regular can of corned beef — the price hadn't gone down, it had increased.

title.children: Hundreds of consumers took matters into their own hands to keep the big supermarkets accountable

image.altText: Hurricane Milton

props.synopsis: Hundreds of thousands of residents in Florida's Tampa region are bracing for the second major hurricane in weeks, Milton set to make landfall as a category five storm on Wednesday.

title.children: What to know about 'explosively' intensifying Hurricane Milton as it speeds toward Florida

image.altText: Cyber hacking

props.synopsis: Australian businesses who make ransomware payments to hackers could be forced to report their actions to authorities under new cybersecurity laws being introduced to parliament on Wednesday.

title.children: Businesses encouraged to share private data with government agencies, under new cyber laws to fight ransomware threat

image.altText: Katy Gallagher portrait

props.synopsis: The Flinders University study found the first year of the entitlement was a success but recommended greater education about the scheme for both employers and employees.

title.children: Paid domestic violence leave underutilised in first year

image.altText: A shopping trolley full of essentials items like fruit, water, and eggs.

props.synopsis: ABS figures show only 6.5 per cent of the population meets the daily requirement of five servings of vegetables and the effects are being felt across the economy.

title.children: Australians are not eating enough vegetables and it's not just our health that is suffering

image.altText: Timelapse of a sky from twilight to night, with antennas scattered across the landscape.

props.synopsis: If there are aliens out there, we'll find them. That's the message from the team behind one of the world's biggest science projects being built in remote Australia.

title.children: 'Leakage from electronics': A giant telescope in the Aussie outback could answer one of humanity's biggest questions

image.altText: Peter Dutton yelling in the House of Representatives.

props.synopsis: The opposition leader fiercely condemned the prime minister for using the motion for personal political gain and accused him of "talking out of both sides of his mouth".

title.children: Coalition refuses to support motion marking the first anniversary of the October 7 attacks

image.altText: A sign reading "Toretsk" painted in blue and yellow next to a small tower on a small hill.

props.synopsis: Russia, which now controls just under a fifth of Ukrainian territory, has been advancing towards Toretsk since August.

title.children: Russian forces advance on Ukraine frontline city after Crimea oil depot attack

image.altText: A navy blue sign with the words Nobel Prize in Physics 2024.

props.synopsis: The scientists won the award for their discoveries and inventions that enable machine learning within artificial neural networks.

title.children: Scientists win Nobel Prize in Physics for developing methods that are 'the foundation' of AI

image.altText: a woman wearing a face mask walking in front of street art

props.synopsis: Australia has recorded its first cases of the XEC COVID-19 variant that has been spreading in Europe this year. Here's what you need to know about XEC — the highly transmissible strain that has been reported in 29 countries.

title.children: A highly transmissible COVID-19 variant has arrived in Australia. What you need to know about XEC

image.altText: The Israeli flag hanging from the frame of a house.

props.synopsis: One year ago, Hamas militants infiltrated Be'eri kibbutz. It was one of many coordinated attacks across Israel that began the Israel-Hamas war — and a delayed response by the Israeli defence force has been blamed for some of the 101 deaths, and dozens taken hostage.

title.children: Heroism, heartbreak and hundreds dead: Inside the Be'eri massacre

image.altText: A man pointing at a screen. There are students behind him.

props.synopsis: Swinburne University's Matthew Bailes has been recognised for his role in discovering fast radio bursts, which are now used by scientists to learn about the Universe.

title.children: Astrophysicist wins 2024 PM's Prize for Science for fast radio burst discovery

image.altText: A woman's hands hold a smartphone in shadow.

props.synopsis: Australia's tech laws are outdated, experts say, but mandating platforms like X or Facebook to prevent harm in the first place could avoid hate speech and disinformation entirely.

title.children: How Brazil managed to bring X in line — and why an Australian duty of care could do the same

image.altText: A man wearing a light blue collared shirt and yellow tie sits at a wooden desk in front of a navy curtain against a white wall.

props.synopsis: Deputy governor Andrew Hauser says the RBA will keep having off-the-record briefings with private banks, despite some attendees leaking details of conversation.

title.children: RBA deputy governor defends private briefings with banks, says oil price isn't a 'top-three risk' right now

image.altText: robbie katter speaking to media

props.synopsis: Katter's Australian Party says it will aim to wind back Queensland abortion laws "quick as you like" with a repeal bill.

title.children: Katter's Australian Party says it will try to repeal Queensland's abortion laws

image.altText: A performer shines a torch towards another performer dressed as a turtle.

props.synopsis: Green sea turtles in the Torres Strait are under threat from climate change. These Torres Strait artists are using Bangarra Dance Theatre's first show for kids to tell their story to people all over the country.

title.children: How do you talk to kids about the threat climate change poses to their home? Through the power of dance
